Saturday, July 23.speaker: Hannah Wayment-Steele
Saturday, July 23.abstract: Therapeutics based on messenger RNA (mRNA) emerged as vaccine forerunners in the COVID-19 pandemic and show immense promise. However, the inherent chemical instability of RNA molecules sets a fundamental limit on the stability of mRNA vaccines, and has created barriers for equitable worldwide vaccine distribution. I  will talk about our efforts to develop a principled biophysical model for RNA degradation, and how we used this model to launch Eterna design challenges. Our studies indicated that the half-life of any mRNA can be immediately increased at least two-fold through sequence design. We further created a machine learning model, trained on degradation data from thousands of player-designed short RNA fragments, which revealed novel sequence- and structure-specific degradation patterns, and demonstrated improved predictive power in independent tests of experimentally-characterized mRNA half-lives. We anticipate this work will be formative for guiding future therapeutic and vaccine development in potency and stability.

Sunday, July 24.speaker: Sarah Smaga, PhD
Sunday, July 24.topic: C-GEM 101: Bespoke molecules from an ancient ribozyme
Sunday, July 24.abstract: The NSF Center for Genetically Encoded Materials (C-GEM) is establishing a fundamentally new way to program chemical matter. We are achieving this goal by expanding the chemical capacity of the ribosome, the ubiquitous molecular machine that translates an mRNA code into a protein of defined sequence and length. We envision a future where materials (polymers) and medicines (natural products) could be programmed in the same way. This talk will introduce the Center’s scientific focus and achievements, and highlight how players contribute to our goals through lab puzzles.

Sunday, July 24.speaker: Slava Butkovich (Anamfija)
Sunday, July 24.abstract: This presentation will demonstrate how the Chimera and ChimeraX molecular modeling programs can be used to visualize 3D RNA structures interactively. Knowledge of these free-to-use programs can empower Eterna players by providing more information and tools with which to design and analyze RNA.

Sunday, July 24.speaker: Rachael Kretsch
Sunday, July 24.topic: RNA in 3D - How does it work?
Sunday, July 24.abstract: It's time to think about how RNA folds in 3D! By playing Eterna you learn how to design stems of base-pairs, but in 3D stems are not just a 2D ladder but a 3D helix, like a spiral staircase. This is only the simplest level of 3D structure, stems and loops can fold into well defined shapes. We will take a look at some tertiary contacts and how they help RNA fold in 3D. We also will look at the ultimate 3D structure resource, the PDB, and highlight some key values that can help you assess the quality of structures.

Sunday, July 24.speaker: Janet Iwasa
Sunday, July 24.abstract: Life as we know it relies on the constant tireless work of tiny molecular machines. My work focuses on creating animations and illustrations of how these machines are hypothesized to operate, based on a variety of data collected by molecular biologists. In this talk, I'll discuss the process of creating molecular animations, how these visualizations help researchers better understand and communicate hypotheses, and share a few past and current projects.

Sunday, July 24.topic: Exploring Structure-Sequence Space Using Image-to-Image Translation

Sunday, July 24.speaker: Michael Stone
Sunday, July 24.topic: Streamlining the discovery of antisense oligonucleotide (ASO) therapeutics
Sunday, July 24.abstract: Antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) are promising therapeutic agents for human diseases. The mechanism of action of ASO drugs can vary widely; however, in all cases the ASO drug must bind stably and specifically to its target RNA to elicit the desired therapeutic outcome. In this talk, I will review examples of successful deployment of ASO therapeutics and highlight challenges to scaling this technology. Next, I will review current research efforts at the University of California, Santa Cruz to develop a rapid and cost-effective ASO design platform. I will conclude with several concepts for ASO design Eterna puzzles.

Sunday, July 24.topic: EternaNext: Setting the Foundation for the Next Decade of Eterna
Sunday, July 24.abstract: The Eterna project and our amazing community have generated amazing new scientific discoveries and achieved significant milestones over the last 11 years. Looking to the future, the Eterna development team has identified several key areas in which we can improve our platform to provide a more powerful and fun experience for our users. In this session, core developers will discuss the rewrite effort and share some of the new features we're excited about.
